newsitem.title: UK: Perky dollar offers lucrative bond trading opportunities.
newsitem.headline: Perky dollar offers lucrative bond trading opportunities.

text.p: The relentless rise of the U.S. dollar, unchecked by weekend comments from the Group of Seven, offers a number of lucrative spread trading opportunities for the bond investors, strategists said on Monday.
There's still money to made from yen/dollar yield trades, peripheral Europe looks set to outperform core and U.S. Treasuries can gain ground on Bunds, they said.
"You can still make a lot of money on these yen finance trades as long as the dollar stays where it is," said Yamaichi international bond strategist Adam Chester.
"You're borrowing money for around one to three percent in the yen market and just on yield pick-up if you put that in Treasuries you can get seven percent."
Chester said the benefits of that trade would unravel if intervention reversed the dollar's rise, or if Treasuries sold off on uncomfortable U.S. data.

The U.S. dollar surged on Monday after a weekend meeting of the Group of Seven (G7) nations agreed on a surprisingly low-key statement that dealers took as a signal the U.S. currency's rise was not over.
They said on Sunday that major currency misalignments had been corrected and that excessive currency volatility and deviations from fundamentals were undesirable.
By late morning, the dollar was at 126.75/85 against the yen, off its overnight high of 127.10. Dollar/mark was at 1.7318/23, down from 1.7395 overnight.
Chester said such dollar strength argued for near term outperformance by U.S. Treasuries over Europe.
"At 116 basis points, the Treasury/Bund spread looks to be good value at these levels," he said, but added risks remained for the long bond as it braced itself for a fraught week littered with data.
Credit Suisse First Boston bond strategist David Keeble said Scandinavian bonds may emerge as winners in the present period of dollar strength.
"Where you're looking for most gains to come will probably be in the high yielder type play -- on the proviso that politics don't turn badly there," he said.
"If the dollar rises, these spreads tend to narrow."

He said Scandinavian debt looked favourable, especially for those investors who wanted to steer clear of Italy, and added Swedish bonds in particular offered some hefty pick-ups over Germany at present.
"But if you really want to take on risk buy Italy," he said.
Keeble said in terms of Treasuries versus European bonds as a whole, he expected U.S. outperformance.
"I think that spread will narrow down to 105 basis points in the next two to three weeks," he said. By 1130 GMT, the Treasury/Bund spread was at 116 basis points.
Sonja Gibbs, senior bond strategist at Nomura International here, also said continued strength in the dollar should be good for European peripherals.
She added there was still life in Japanese Government Bond (JGB) versus U.S. Treasury carry trades.
"I think there's still good potential in carry trades, not necessarily to put on new ones, but to let the old ones go," she said.
"Long live the carry trade."
